1.title: Work on One Sub-Feature at a Time
1.content: Restricts focus to a single sub-feature per coding session to maintain clarity and prevent scope creep.

2.title: Enforce 50 LOC Change Limit
2.content: Enforces 50-line maximum change limit with explicit override requirement.

3.title: Keep Diffs Minimal
3.content: Requires minimal, focused code changes to reduce review complexity.

4.title: Synchronize Comments with Code Changes
4.content: Mandates comment updates occur simultaneously with code changes.

5.title: Use Short Sentences in Comments
5.content: Limits comment sentences to 20 words maximum for readability.

6.title: Use Simple English Vocabulary
6.content: Requires everyday vocabulary accessible to 8th-grade reading level.

7.title: Avoid Unexplained Technical Jargon
7.content: Prohibits technical jargon without plain English explanations.

8.title: Use Active Voice
8.content: Mandates active voice for clearer communication.

9.title: Use Bullets for Step Explanations
9.content: Specifies bullet point format for procedural explanations.

10.title: Explain Design Decisions Not Code
10.content: Directs comments toward rationale rather than code restatement.

11.title: Include Comprehensive File Headers
11.content: Requires file headers explaining purpose, dependencies, contracts, risks.

12.title: Document Import Rationale
12.content: Mandates organized import documentation with rationale.

13.title: Document Public APIs Completely
13.content: Specifies comprehensive API documentation covering purpose, behavior, errors, security.

14.title: Document Non-Obvious Variables
14.content: Requires detailed variable documentation including meaning, units, ranges, rationale.

15.title: Provide Logic PLAN/RATIONALE Blocks
15.content: Mandates pre-logic explanation blocks for complex conditional/iterative code.

16.title: Document Configuration Settings
16.content: Requires configuration documentation including safety rationale and constraints.

17.title: Document Service Business Rules
17.content: Mandates business rule documentation and external dependency mapping.

18.title: Document Logging Purpose and Rules
18.content: Specifies logging purpose, data protection, traceability requirements.

19.title: Document Receipt Audit Trails
19.content: Defines audit trail requirements with timestamp and context data.

20.title: Document Database Migration Safety
20.content: Requires migration justification, zero-downtime strategy, recovery procedures.

21.title: Document Blob Storage Specifications
21.content: Mandates binary data documentation including format, size, paths, privacy.

22.title: Document Backup Operations
22.content: Specifies backup operational parameters, retention, verification.

23.title: Document Audit Trail Integrity
23.content: Defines audit immutability, authorship, integrity verification.

24.title: Prohibit Secrets and PII in Comments
24.content: Prohibits sensitive information; mandates synthetic test data.

25.title: Enforce Output Format Standards
25.content: Restricts output to Unified Diff, New File, or JSON only.

26.title: Enforce TODO Accountability
26.content: Requires accountability for unfinished work with owner, date, ticket.

27.title: Enforce Policy and Contract Links
27.content: Requires explicit linking to governing contracts/policies.

28.title: Maintain Complete Documentation Coverage
28.content: Mandates comprehensive documentation across all required locations.

29.title: Include Quantitative Context
29.content: Requires quantitative context for values including units, ranges.

30.title: Synchronize Comment and Code Presentation
30.content: Requires synchronized display of code and comment changes.

31.title: Prioritize Determinism Over Speed
31.content: Reproducible test runs are superior to fast but flaky runs.

32.title: Eliminate Test-Result Caching
32.content: Disable or purge all framework caches before every run.

33.title: Enforce Hermetic Test Runs
33.content: Tests must not access network, system clocks, global OS state, or previous runs.

34.title: Maintain Test Independence
34.content: Tests must pass when run alone or in any sequence.

35.title: Maintain Standard Repository Structure
35.content: Use src/, tests/ with subdirectories unit/, component/, integration/, fixtures/, helpers/.

37.title: Purge Cache Directories Pre-Execution
37.content: Delete Python, Node.js, and tooling caches before test execution.

38.title: Disable Framework Caching
38.content: Use framework-specific flags to disable caching mechanisms.

39.title: Maintain Unit Test Purity
39.content: Unit tests must be pure functions with no I/O, network, or time dependencies.

40.title: Use Table-Driven Test Structure
40.content: Unit tests must use table-driven tests for clarity.

41.title: Use In-Memory Doubles for Component Tests
41.content: Component tests must use in-memory doubles only for cross-module interactions.

42.title: Use Real Adapters for Integration Tests
42.content: Integration tests must use real adapters with isolated instances.

43.title: Prohibit Internet Access in Tests
43.content: No calls to public Internet in unit, component, or integration tests.

44.title: Control Randomness and Time
44.content: All randomness must be seeded; time must be frozen or explicitly controlled.

45.title: Prohibit Test Retries
45.content: Flaky tests are bugs; do not mask with retries.

46.title: Organize Fixtures and Data
46.content: Fixtures under tests/fixtures/, read-only, prefer synthetic data, hash large fixtures.

47.title: Generate Test Evidence
47.content: Emit jUnit XML reports and run manifest with seeds, versions, and hashes.

48.title: Design AI-Generated Tests Deterministically
48.content: Assume cache purging, use TEST_RANDOM_SEED, compose hermetic tests.

49.title: Organize AI-Generated Tests Properly
49.content: Place tests in correct directories, use pure helpers, minimize dependencies.

50.title: Ensure AI-Generated Test Quality
50.content: Limit test scope, provide complete implementations, create actionable failures.

51.title: Enforce Quality Gates
51.content: All tests must pass, no network access, valid artifacts, cache elimination verified.

52.title: Conduct Comprehensive Test Reviews
52.content: Verify determinism, completeness, organization, harness usage, artifacts, cache elimination.

53.title: Fixture rule intentionally disabled for exclusion validation
53.content: Disabled-only rule used to verify loaders exclude non-enabled rules.

54.title: Require Schema Version in Logs
54.content: All log entries must include the log_schema_version field set to "1.0" to ensure consistent parsing and schema validation across all logging systems.

55.title: Use JSONL Format for Logs
55.content: All log entries must use JSONL format with exactly one JSON object per line for consistent parsing and processing.

56.title: Standardize Timestamp Format
56.content: All timestamps must use ISO-8601 UTC format with monotonic hardware time for precise ordering.

57.title: Require Monotonic Time Precision
57.content: Use high-precision monotonic time sources and convert to milliseconds for consistent timing measurements.

58.title: Enforce UTF-8 Encoding
58.content: Ensure consistent character encoding without BOM and prevent multi-line log entries.

59.title: Ensure Cross-Platform Compatibility
59.content: Maintain log integrity across Windows and other platforms with proper line endings and path length limits.

60.title: Define Output Destination Rules
60.content: Specify different output destinations for development vs production environments.

61.title: Require Timestamp Fields
61.content: All log entries must include both UTC and monotonic hardware timestamps for temporal correlation.

62.title: Enforce Log Level Enumeration
62.content: Standardize log level values to ensure consistent severity classification across all services.

63.title: Require Service Identification
63.content: All logs must include service metadata for proper attribution and filtering in distributed systems.

64.title: Enforce Distributed Tracing Context
64.content: Implement W3C trace context propagation and generate missing tracing identifiers.

65.title: Do Exactly What's Asked
65.content: If your friend asks you to make a peanut butter sandwich, don't add jelly unless they ask for it. Follow instructions exactly without adding your own ideas.

66.title: Only Use Information You're Given
66.content: If you're baking cookies and the recipe doesn't say how much sugar to use, stop and ask. Don't guess or make up an amount.

67.title: Protect People's Privacy
67.content: Treat everyone's personal information like a secret diary. Don't look at it, don't share it, and definitely don't write it down where others can see it.

68.title: Use Settings Files, Not Hardcoded Numbers
68.content: Instead of writing 'use 10 apples' in your recipe, write 'use [number] apples' and keep the number 10 in a separate note. This way you can easily change to 12 apples later.

69.title: Keep Good Records
69.content: Like keeping a science lab notebook - write down what you did, when you did it, and what happened. Use the format your teacher asks for, and don't add extra stuff they didn't request.

70.title: Never Break Things During Updates
70.content: When updating a video game, you should still be able to play while it updates. If the update causes problems, you can instantly switch back to the old version.

71.title: Make Things Fast
71.content: Optimize performance for all operations. Like a fast computer game - everything should respond quickly, not make people wait.

72.title: Be Honest About AI Decisions
72.content: When AI suggests something, it should say:

73.title: Check Your Data
73.content: Make sure the AI's training data is like a fair test - balanced questions, up-to-date information, and correct answers.

74.title: Keep AI Safe
74.content: AI should only work in a special 'playground' (sandbox) away from real computers. It can look at code and make suggestions, but never actually run code on people's machines.

75.title: Learn from Mistakes
75.content: When the AI gets something wrong, it should remember that mistake and get smarter, just like you learn from getting test questions wrong.

76.title: Test Everything
76.content: Always try things out before saying they work. Don't break things that already work. Test both simple cases and tricky situations.

77.title: Write Good Instructions
77.content: Give people working examples they can try themselves, clear explanations of how to use things, and troubleshooting guides for when things go wrong.

78.title: Keep Good Logs
78.content: Write clear notes that are easy to read, use special tracking numbers to follow requests through the system, and measure both technical numbers and business results.

79.title: Make Changes Easy to Undo
79.content: Prefer adding new features rather than changing old ones. Use on/off switches for features. Write down how to go back if something doesn't work.

80.title: Make Things Repeatable
80.content: Write down exactly what ingredients (versions) you used. Don't depend on special kitchen equipment (computer setups). Include simple steps so others can recreate your work.

81.title: Keep Different Parts Separate
81.content: The display screen (user interface) only shows information. The thinking part (business logic) only does calculations. Never mix these two jobs.

82.title: Be Fair to Everyone
82.content: Use clear, simple language everyone can understand. Don't use tricky designs that might confuse people. Make sure people with disabilities can use everything.

83.title: Make All 20 Modules Look the Same
83.content: All 18 tools should use the same buttons, menus, and look. Like different rooms in the same house - they have the same light switches and door handles.

84.title: Process Data Locally First
84.content: Process data on the local device first before sending to servers. Like doing homework at your desk before turning it in - handle what you can locally to reduce delays and server load.

85.title: Don't Make People Configure Before Using
85.content: Things should work right out of the box. Like a new video game - you can start playing immediately, and only set up complex controls later if you want.

86.title: Show Information Gradually
86.content: Show information to users gradually, not all at once. Like a storybook - reveal pages one at a time so people can understand each part before moving to the next.

87.title: Organize Features Clearly
87.content: 18 Main Areas  Specific Features  Detailed Tools Like a school: School  Grade Levels  Classrooms  Subjects

88.title: Be Smart About Data
88.content: Be intelligent about how you handle data - use it efficiently and only when needed. Like a smart shopping list - only get what you need, when you need it.

89.title: Work Without Internet
89.content: Core features must work offline, like being able to write in a notebook when you don't have WiFi. Save actions and sync when you're back online.

90.title: Register Modules the Same Way
90.content: All 18 modules should sign up using the same process, like every student using the same enrollment form.

91.title: Make All Modules Feel Like One Product
91.content: Use the same command names everywhere, make status indicators look the same, handle errors the same way - like different apps made by the same company.

92.title: Design for Quick Adoption
92.content: Design systems so new users can start using them quickly without extensive training. Like a simple video game - you can play immediately, and learn advanced moves later.

93.title: Test User Experience
93.content: Test how users actually experience your system, not just if it works. Like taste-testing food before serving - make sure it's good for the people eating it, not just technically correct.

94.title: Solve Real Developer Problems
94.content: Every feature must fix a real frustration developers face, like making homework easier by having better tools.

95.title: Help People Work Better
95.content: Build tools that help people work better and more efficiently. Like giving someone a better tool for their job - it should make their work easier and more effective.

96.title: Prevent Problems Before They Happen
96.content: Stop issues before they become big problems, like fixing a small leak before it floods the house.

97.title: Be Extra Careful with Private Data
97.content: Be extremely careful when handling private or sensitive data. Like locking a diary - treat personal information with extra security and respect.

98.title: Don't Make People Think Too Hard
98.content: Fix common issues with one click, give suggestions without interrupting, automate boring tasks, teach as you go - like having a helpful friend.

99.title: MMM Engine - Change Behavior
99.content: Help people stop making the same mistakes, increase use of best practices, reduce need for manual fixes, help people solve problems themselves - like a good habit coach.

100.title: Detection Engine - Be Accurate
100.content: The detection engine must be accurate and reliable. Like a good security system - it should correctly identify real problems without false alarms.

101.title: Risk Modules - Safety First
101.content: Never make situations worse, always provide undo options, support gradual improvements, verify before big changes - like safety rules in science lab.

102.title: Success Dashboards - Show Business Value
102.content: Connect engineering work to company results, show money saved and time gained, track both current and future benefits - like showing how studying leads to better grades.

104.title: Process Data Quickly
104.content: Handle urgent data in less than 1 second (like answering important texts immediately), group less important data (like checking regular mail once a day), check data quality as it comes in.

105.title: Help Without Interrupting
105.content: Give help when needed, not before (like waiting to be asked), match help to how complex the task is (like simple vs complex instructions), let experts turn off basic help.

106.title: Handle Emergencies Well
106.content: Make the right action obvious (like big red stop button), provide one-click solutions, offer multiple ways to recover, show clear progress updates - like good emergency instructions.

107.title: Make Developers Happier
107.content: Reduce time spent switching between tasks, cut down on boring repetitive work, increase time spent on meaningful coding, build confidence in deployments - like making schoolwork more enjoyable.

108.title: Track Problems You Prevent
108.content: Count security issues caught early, track deployment failures avoided, measure knowledge gaps found and fixed, watch technical debt prevented - like counting accidents that didn't happen because of safety measures.

109.title: Build Compliance into Workflow
109.content: Check rules automatically during development, monitor compliance in real-time, generate audit reports easily, assess impact of rule changes - like having built-in spell check while writing.

110.title: Security Should Help, Not Block
110.content: Security tips shouldn't break concentration, automate common security fixes, explain security rules in simple terms, prioritize security risks by importance - like friendly security guards rather than prison guards.

111.title: Support Gradual Adoption
111.content: Let teams start with 3-5 most useful modules, each module should work well on its own, show clear paths to add more modules, provide value at every step - like learning math starting with addition, then multiplication.

112.title: Scale from Small to Huge
112.content: Work for 1 developer or 10,000, handle 100 events per day or 10 million, support simple systems and complex ones, meet basic needs and strict regulations - like a playground that works for both small kids and professional athletes.

113.title: Build for Real Team Work
113.content: Make collaboration natural and easy, help teams share knowledge automatically, reduce meetings and emails through better tools, make it easy to help each other without interrupting work - like good group project tools.

114.title: Prevent Knowledge Silos
114.content: Automatically identify who knows what, suggest when to share important information, help teams learn from each other's successes, make expertise easy to find when needed - like knowing which friend to ask for help with different subjects.

115.title: Reduce Frustration Daily
115.content: Fix the small annoyances that add up, automate boring repetitive tasks, make hard things easier, celebrate small wins and progress - like making daily chores less annoying.

116.title: Build Confidence, Not Fear
116.content: Make deployments feel safe and controlled, provide safety nets for mistakes, show progress and improvements clearly, help people learn without embarrassment - like training wheels on a bike.

117.title: Learn and Adapt Constantly
117.content: Watch how people actually use the product, learn from what works and what doesn't, make the product smarter over time, adapt to different team styles and needs - like a teacher who adjusts to how students learn best.

118.title: Measure What Matters
118.content: Track real improvements, not just activity, measure time saved and stress reduced, watch for positive behavior changes, count problems prevented, not just fixed - like measuring learning, not just time spent studying.

119.title: Catch Issues Early
119.content: Find problems when they're small and easy to fix, warn about potential issues before they happen, suggest simple fixes for common mistakes, prevent small issues from becoming big problems - like fixing a small leak before it becomes a flood.

120.title: Build Safety Into Everything
120.content: Always have an 'undo' button, make dangerous actions hard to do accidentally, provide multiple ways to recover from mistakes, test changes safely before applying them - like safety features in cars.

121.title: Automate Wisely
121.content: Only automate things that are boring or error-prone, always let people review and approve important changes, make automation helpful, not annoying, explain what the automation is doing and why - like a helpful robot assistant.

122.title: Learn from Experts
122.content: Watch how the best developers work, copy their successful patterns, help everyone work like the experts, share best practices across the whole team - like learning sports from professional athletes.

123.title: Show the Right Information at the Right Time
123.content: Don't overwhelm people with too much information, show what's important right now, hide complexity until it's needed, make status and progress clear at a glance - like a good car dashboard.

124.title: Make Dependencies Visible
124.content: Show how different pieces connect and depend on each other, warn when changes might affect other people, help teams coordinate without meetings, make the system's architecture easy to understand - like a map showing how roads connect.

125.title: Be Predictable and Consistent
125.content: Work the same way every time, don't surprise people with unexpected behavior, explain clearly what will happen before it happens, build trust through reliability - like a reliable friend.

126.title: Never Lose People's Work
126.content: Save work automatically and frequently, provide clear recovery options, back up important information, warn before doing anything that can't be undone - like automatic save in video games.

127.title: Make it Beautiful and Pleasant
127.content: Use clean, attractive designs, choose pleasant colors and fonts, make interactions smooth and satisfying, create an experience people enjoy using - like a well-designed park.

128.title: Respect People's Time
128.content: Load quickly and respond instantly, don't make people wait unnecessarily, streamline common tasks, value every second of people's time - like express checkout lines.

129.title: Handle Edge Cases Gracefully
129.content: Plan for things going wrong, handle errors without crashing, provide helpful error messages, recover smoothly from problems - like having a plan B when things don't go as expected.

130.title: Encourage Better Ways of Working
130.content: Suggest improvements to processes, help teams adopt better practices, make good habits easy to form, reward continuous improvement - like a good coach.

131.title: Adapt to Different Skill Levels
131.content: Help beginners learn quickly, support experts with advanced features, don't force one way of working on everyone, grow with people as they learn and improve - like books with different reading levels.

132.title: Be Helpful, Not Annoying
132.content: Offer help when it's actually needed, know when to be quiet and stay out of the way, learn what kind of help each person prefers, get better at helping over time - like a helpful friend who knows when to help and when to let you figure things out.

133.title: Explain AI Decisions Clearly
133.content: Don't be a 'black box' - show your reasoning, help people understand why you're making suggestions, be honest about uncertainty and limitations, build trust through transparency - like showing your math work instead of just the answer.

134.title: Demonstrate Clear Value
134.content: Show how the product saves time and money, make benefits obvious and measurable, connect features to real business outcomes, prove your worth every day - like showing how studying leads to better grades.

135.title: Grow with the Customer
135.content: Work well for small teams and huge organizations, adapt to different industries and needs, support both simple and complex situations, scale smoothly as needs grow - like clothes that can expand as you grow.

136.title: Create 'Magic Moments'
136.content: Occasionally surprise and delight users, make some tasks feel effortless and magical, exceed expectations in small, meaningful ways, create features that people love to show others - like finding an extra french fry at the bottom of the bag.

137.title: Remove Friction Everywhere
137.content: Eliminate unnecessary steps and clicks, simplify complex processes, make common tasks fast and easy, smooth out rough edges in the experience - like making doors automatic so you don't have to push them.

138.title: Roles & Scope
138.content: Define clear roles and scope for each person or component. Like a team sport - everyone knows their position and what they're responsible for.

139.title: Golden Rules (non-negotiable)
139.content: Golden rules are non-negotiable principles that must always be followed. Like traffic laws - these are fundamental rules that everyone must obey for safety and order.

140.title: Review Outcomes & Severity
140.content: Review outcomes and determine their severity levels. Like a doctor checking symptoms - assess how serious problems are and prioritize accordingly.

141.title: Stop Conditions  Error Codes (CI/Reviewer)
141.content: Define stop conditions that map to specific error codes for CI and reviewers. Like emergency codes at a hospital - each condition has a clear code that tells everyone what's wrong.

142.title: Review Procedure (simple checklist)
142.content: Use a simple checklist for review procedures. Like a pilot's pre-flight checklist - follow a clear, step-by-step list to ensure nothing is missed.

143.title: Evidence Required in PR
143.content: Require evidence in pull requests to prove changes work. Like showing your homework - provide proof that you've done the work correctly.

144.title: Automation (CI/Pre-commit)
144.content: Automate checks through CI and pre-commit hooks. Like a robot assistant - let automated systems check things so humans don't have to remember everything.

145.title: Review Comment Style (simple English)
145.content: Use simple English in review comments so everyone can understand. Like explaining to a friend - use clear, straightforward language without technical jargon.

146.title: Return Contracts (review output)
146.content: Document return contracts in review output. Like a recipe that says what you'll get - clearly state what each function or method returns so reviewers know what to expect.

148.title: STOP CONDITIONS  ERROR CODES- Python/TS lint or format changes needed  ERROR:STYLE_VIOLATION
148.content: STOP CONDITIONS  ERROR CODES: When Python/TypeScript lint or format changes are needed, use error code ERROR:STYLE_VIOLATION. This signals that code style requirements have not been met.

149.title: Optional PR Template (drop in .github/pull_request_template.md)
149.content: Provide an optional PR template that can be dropped into .github/pull_request_template.md. Like a form - give people a template to fill out so they include all necessary information.

150.title: SELF-AUDIT BEFORE OUTPUT- [ ] File header has What/Why/Reads-Writes/Contracts/Risks
150.content: SELF-AUDIT BEFORE OUTPUT: Verify that file headers include required sections: What the file does, Why it exists, What it reads/writes, Contracts/APIs, and Risks. This must be checked before code is considered complete.

151.title: STOP CONDITIONS  ERROR CODES- Missing file header or public API docstring . ERROR:COMMENT_MISSING
151.content: STOP CONDITIONS  ERROR CODES: When file header or public API docstring is missing, use error code ERROR:COMMENT_MISSING. This indicates required documentation is absent.

152.title: Comments in Simple English
152.content: Explain what and why in short sentences. Avoid jargon.

153.title: STOP CONDITIONS  ERROR CODES- Spectral lint failure  ERROR:OPENAPI_LINT_FAIL
153.content: STOP CONDITIONS  ERROR CODES: When Spectral lint fails (OpenAPI validation), use error code ERROR:OPENAPI_LINT_FAIL. This indicates OpenAPI specification violations.

154.title: RECEIPTS, LOGGING & EVIDENCE- For any privileged action, append an INTENT receipt (JSONL) BEFORE writing code/data; then append a RESULT receipt after.
154.content: RECEIPTS, LOGGING & EVIDENCE: For any privileged action, append an INTENT receipt (JSONL) BEFORE writing code/data; then append a RESULT receipt after. This creates an audit trail of what was intended and what actually happened.

155.title: Prevent First
155.content: Validate inputs early (required, type, range, size). Prevention beats cure.

156.title: Small, Stable Error Codes
156.content: Adopt ~1012 canonical codes with severity levels:

157.title: Wrap & Chain
157.content: When a low-level error occurs, wrap it into your code with a friendly message and keep the original as the cause. Never throw raw framework/driver errors at the edges.

158.title: Central Handler at Boundaries
158.content: Have one handler per surface (API endpoint, CLI entry, IDE command) that:

159.title: Friendly to Users, Detailed in Logs
159.content: Users see short, calm guidance. Logs contain context and the cause chain. Never leak secrets.

160.title: No Silent Catches
160.content: Never swallow errors. If you catch it, either fix, retry (if safe), or wrap & bubble to the central handler.

161.title: Add Context
161.content: Always include where/what (operation name, ids, step) when wrapping. This speeds up root-cause analysis.

162.title: Cleanup Always
162.content: Close files, sockets, timers; release locks. Use 'always-run' cleanup paths. Avoid resource leaks.

163.title: Error Recovery Patterns
163.content: Define clear recovery actions for each error type:

164.title: New Developer Onboarding - Provide 'First Error Handling Task' template
164.content: Provide new developers with a 'First Error Handling Task' template during onboarding. Like a training exercise - give new team members a clear, structured way to learn error handling.

165.title: Timeouts Everywhere
165.content: All I/O (network, file, DB, subprocess) must have a timeout (configurable). No infinite waits.

166.title: Limited Retries with Backoff
166.content: Retry only idempotent operations. Max 23 tries. Use exponential backoff + small jitter.

167.title: Do Not Retry Non-Retriables
167.content: No retries for validation errors, 401/403, 404, or business rule failures. Surface the issue; guide the user.

168.title: Idempotency
168.content: Design writes so they are safe to retry (keys/tokens/conflict handling). Document this in your service contract.

169.title: (Reserved) See Rule 165: HTTP/Exit Mapping.
169.content: This rule is reserved. See Rule 165 (R-165) for HTTP/Exit Mapping requirements. Rule 165 defines how HTTP status codes map to exit codes and error handling patterns.

170.title: HTTP/Exit Mapping
170.content: Map canonical codes to standard outcomes (e.g., 400/401/403/404/409/422/429/5xx). No '200 with error body'.

171.title: Message Catalog
171.content: Keep a single catalog that maps each code  one friendly, human sentence. Translate here, not in code.

172.title: UI/IDE Behavior
172.content: Keep UI responsive. Show short, actionable options: Retry / Cancel / Open Logs. No stack traces to users.

173.title: Structured Logs
173.content: One JSON object per line. Include: timestamp, level, service, operation, error.code, trace/request ids, duration, attempt, retryable flag, severity, and a cause chain summary.

174.title: Correlation
174.content: Propagate trace/request ids across calls. Log exactly one request.start and one request.end per request.

175.title: Privacy & Secrets
175.content: Never log secrets or PII. Redact tokens, passwords, cookies, Authorization headers, and sensitive payloads. Log sizes/hashes, not raw bodies.

176.title: Test Failure Paths
176.content: Write tests for error paths and failure scenarios to ensure the system handles failures gracefully. Like testing a car's brakes - make sure things work when something goes wrong, not just when everything works perfectly.

177.title: Contracts & Docs
177.content: Document the error envelope, code list, HTTP mapping, and examples. Keep examples up to date and non-PII.

178.title: Consistency Over Cleverness
178.content: Prefer consistent handling over one-off fixes. If a new case appears, map it to an existing code first.

179.title: Safe Defaults
179.content: Default timeouts, retry caps, and user messages must be safe and configurable. No hidden magic numbers.

180.title: RECEIPTS & GOVERNANCE- Emit JSONL receipts for: contract.publish, contract.diff, contract.violation.
180.content: RECEIPTS & GOVERNANCE: Emit JSONL receipts for contract.publish, contract.diff, and contract.violation events. These receipts provide governance evidence of contract-related activities.

182.title: AI Sandbox Safety
182.content: AI should only work in a special 'playground' (sandbox) away from real computers. It can look at code and make suggestions, but never actually run code on people's machines.

183.title: AI Learning from Mistakes
183.content: When the AI gets something wrong, it should remember that mistake and get smarter, just like learning from test questions.

184.title: AI Confidence Thresholds
184.content: High confidence (>90%): Apply automatically with user notification

185.title: NO Complex Error Handling
185.content: BANNED: Try-catch blocks, exception handling, error chains

186.title: Graceful Degradation
186.content: When dependencies fail, provide reduced functionality rather than complete failure. Show clear status of what's working vs. limited.

187.title: State Recovery
187.content: After crashes or failures, systems should recover to known good states. Maintain recovery checkpoints for long-running operations.

188.title: Feature Flag Safety
188.content: Use feature flags for risky changes with automatic rollback on error detection. Monitor error rates by flag state.

189.title: Strict Mode Always
189.content: Turn on strict checks everywhere. (Meaning: the compiler catches more mistakes early.)

190.title: Small, Clear Functions
190.content: Short functions, clear names. One job per function.

191.title: Consistent Naming
191.content: Use consistent naming conventions throughout the codebase. Like a library - everything should be organized and labeled the same way so you can find things easily.

192.title: Clear Shape Strategy
192.content: Use interface for object shapes you'll extend, type for unions and utilities. Stay consistent across the repo.

193.title: Let the Compiler Infer
193.content: Don't add types the compiler already knows. (Meaning: avoid noisy annotations.)

194.title: Keep Imports Clean
194.content: No unused imports. Group by built-in, third-party, then local.

195.title: Describe the Shape
195.content: Make simple named types for real data (User, Order). Reuse them.

196.title: Union & Narrowing
196.content: If something can be A or B, say so. Check which one before using it.

197.title: Readonly by Default
197.content: Prefer readonly arrays/props for values that should not change.

198.title: Discriminated Unions
198.content: When you have variants, add a simple kind field and switch on it. (Meaning: safer branching.)

199.title: Utility Types, Not Duplicates
199.content: Use Partial, Pick, Omit, Record to avoid copy-pasting shapes.

200.title: Generics, But Simple
200.content: Use generics when it truly makes code reusable. Keep names short and clear.

201.title: No Unhandled Promises
201.content: Always await or handle .catch. Never let a promise fail silently.

202.title: Timeouts & Cancel
202.content: Use timeouts for network/work that may hang. Support AbortController for cancellable operations.

203.title: Friendly Errors at Edges
203.content: Catch errors at boundaries (commands, routes) and show short, calm messages. Put details in logs (no secrets).

204.title: Map Errors to Codes
204.content: Convert messy errors into a small set of stable codes (e.g., VALIDATION, NOT_FOUND, TIMEOUT, DEPENDENCY_FAILED, UNEXPECTED). Be consistent.

205.title: Retries Are Limited
205.content: Retry only safe (idempotent) actions, at most 23 times, with backoff. Never retry validation or permission errors.

206.title: One Source of Truth
206.content: Keep types for APIs in one place (e.g., generated from contracts). Don't hand-roll duplicates.

207.title: Folder Layout
207.content: Group by feature, then by file type (types, logic, tests). Avoid deep 'barrel' re-exports chains.

208.title: Paths & Aliases
208.content: Use path aliases in config (short imports), but don't create cycles.

209.title: Modern Output Targets
209.content: Target modern JS (ES2022+) for optimal tree-shaking. Keep configs in repo. Builds must be reproducible.

210.title: Lint & Format
210.content: Use eslint + prettier. No warnings in CI.

211.title: Type Check in CI
211.content: Run the compiler (tsc) with strict settings on every PR.

212.title: Tests for New Behavior
212.content: Add tests for new logic and for error paths (timeouts, bad input). Keep tests fast.

213.title: Validate Untrusted Inputs at Runtime
213.content: Types help at build time only. Validate external data before use.

214.title: Keep the UI Responsive
214.content: Do heavy work off the main thread. Show progress for long tasks.

215.title: Review AI Code Thoroughly
215.content: All AI-generated TypeScript must be reviewed by humans. Verify types, error handling, and security match our standards.

216.title: Monitor Bundle Impact
216.content: Use path imports for large libraries. Avoid barrel imports in hot paths. Set bundle size budgets and monitor them.

217.title: Quality Dependencies
217.content: Prefer packages with built-in TypeScript definitions. Use @types/ packages from DefinitelyTyped. Audit dependencies for type safety.

218.title: Test Type Boundaries
218.content: Write tests that verify type narrowing works. Test error cases to ensure proper typing. Use @ts-expect-error for expected type failures.

219.title: Gradual Migration Strategy
219.content: When converting JavaScript to TypeScript, use // @ts-check in JS files first. Add JSDoc types before conversion. Convert one module at a time.

220.title: Write Clean, Readable Code
220.content: Make code easy to understand and modify, use clear names and simple structures, document why decisions were made, keep code organized and consistent - like writing clear, neat notes.

221.title: PR Template Block  Code Review (paste into .github/pull_request_template.md)
221.content: PR Template Block for Code Review - a template section that can be pasted into .github/pull_request_template.md. This provides a standardized format for code review information in pull requests.

222.title: No any in committed code
222.content: If you don't know the type, use unknown and check it before use.

223.title: No Secrets in Code or Logs
223.content: Never commit tokens/passwords. Redact sensitive values from logs.

224.title: Self-Documenting Code
224.content: Code should read like a story, not a puzzle.

225.title: Visual Code Layout
225.content: Use whitespace to group related ideas.

226.title: Code as Documentation
226.content: The code itself should be the primary documentation.

227.title: No Source Code/PII in Stores
227.content: Storage must never contain source code or personally identifiable information (PII). Use handles, IDs, and metadata only. Receipts and evidence stores are for facts about work, not the work itself.

228.title: No Secrets/Private Keys on Disk
228.content: Never store secrets, passwords, API keys, or private keys on disk. Use secrets manager, HSM, or KMS. Only public keys may be stored in trust/pubkeys/. Load sensitive configuration from environment variables or secure vaults.

229.title: Policy Snapshots Must Be Signed
229.content: All policy snapshots and templates must be signed. Laptops cache policies; authoritative publishing happens in the Product plane. Policy files are JSON and signed for integrity verification.

230.title: Path Resolution via ZU_ROOT Environment Variable
230.content: All storage paths must be resolved via ZU_ROOT environment variable or config/paths.json. Never hardcode absolute paths like D:\ZeroUI or /home/user/zeroui. Enables portable, configurable deployments.

231.title: Evidence Watermarks Per-Consumer Structure
231.content: Evidence watermarks must follow per-consumer structure: .../evidence/watermarks/{consumer-id}/. Each consumer (metrics, traces, logs, etc.) has its own watermark directory for tracking processing progress.

232.title: Observability/Adapters Use dt= Partitions
232.content: Observability and adapter paths require date partitions (dt=YYYY-MM-DD):

233.title: Laptop Receipts Use YYYY/MM Partitioning
233.content: Laptop (IDE) receipts use month partitioning: ide/agent/receipts/{repo-id}/{YYYY}/{MM}/. Example: ide/agent/receipts/zeroui2-0/2025/10/. Auxiliary folders (index, quarantine, checkpoints) live under the same repo path.

234.title: (Deprecated) See Rule 226: RFC Fallback Pattern (UNCLASSIFIED__slug, 24h Resolution).
234.content: This rule is deprecated. See Rule 226 (R-226) for RFC Fallback Pattern requirements. Rule 226 defines the UNCLASSIFIED__slug pattern with 24-hour resolution requirements for handling unclassified data.

235.title: (Deprecated) See Rule 227: Observability/Adapters Use dt= Partitions.
235.content: This rule is deprecated. See Rule 227 (R-227) for Observability/Adapters partition requirements. Rule 227 defines how observability and adapters use dt= partitions for data organization.

236.title: (Deprecated) See Rule 228: Laptop Receipts Use YYYY/MM Partitioning.
236.content: This rule is deprecated. See Rule 228 (R-228) for Laptop Receipts partition requirements. Rule 228 defines YYYY/MM partitioning for laptop receipts based on date stamps.

237.title: STORAGE & RETENTION (LAPTOP-FIRST)
237.content: Path: /logs/YYYY-MM-DD/*.jsonl (daily). Rotate at 100MB; keep last 10 files locally.

238.title: Override Storage & Lifecycle
238.content: Store overrides outside gsmd/ (runtime/config store). Log issuance and expiry via receipts. When ttl elapses, the override is invalid without re-approval.

240.title: Read-Only Policy Assets
240.content: You MUST NOT edit or overwrite existing files under gsmd/**. To change policy, create a new version folder (e.g., v2/) and add a new snapshot.json. Keep older versions intact.

241.title: Versioning Is Append-Only
241.content: Breaking or behavioral changes require a new v{major} directory. Do not mutate prior versions. Use the deprecates[] field when formally superseding older snapshots.

244.title: Decision Receipts  Required Fields
244.content: Every GSMD decision MUST emit a signed receipt containing at minimum:

245.title: Receipt Discipline (Append-Only, Signed)
245.content: Receipts are newline-delimited JSON (JSONL), append-only. Never rewrite. Each receipt is signed; reject or quarantine any receipt missing a signature.

246.title: Decisions & Modes (Status Pill)
246.content: Implement decisions using the canonical set only:

247.title: Rollout & Cohorts
247.content: If rollout.cohorts or rollout.ladder are present, enforce exactly as declared. If absent, use rollout.default_mode. Never assume implied cohorts.

248.title: Privacy & Redaction
248.content: Apply any rules present under privacy.redactions before logging or emitting receipts. Never log raw PII or secrets. Log hashes/sizes instead of raw payloads.

249.title: Evidence & Required Receipts
249.content: If evidence.map[] or receipts.required[] are present in the snapshot, collect the named artifacts (or their hashes) and ensure required receipts exist before returning a terminal decision.

250.title: Tests Fixtures Must Match Policy
250.content: Where tests.fixtures[] are present, unit/integration tests MUST prove the declared outcomes (pass | warn | soft_block | hard_block). Do not merge if observed outcomes differ from fixtures.

251.title: Mandatory CI Gates
251.content: Every PR touching policy or enforcement MUST run:

252.title: Release Manifests (Merkle Root)
252.content: Before publishing a policy release, generate a manifest and (optionally) sign it:

253.title: Runtime Snapshot Binding
253.content: At decision time, the engine MUST bind to the exact snapshot referenced by the receipt (policy_version_ids[] and policy_snapshot_hash). Never apply a different snapshot than the one recorded.

254.title: Cursor Behavior for GSMD
254.content: Cursor MUST NOT propose edits under gsmd/**. It MUST:

255.title: Return Contracts for GSMD Artifacts
255.content: For policy work, output only one of:

257.title: Self-Audit Before Output (GSMD)
257.content: [ ] Not editing existing gsmd/**; new version only when needed

258.title: Plain English Variable Names
258.content: Use descriptive, everyday words instead of technical jargon or abbreviations.

259.title: One Concept Per Function
259.content: Each function should do exactly one thing.

260.title: Avoid Mental Gymnastics
260.content: No nested ternary operators, complex one-liners, or clever tricks.

261.title: Use Real-World Analogies
261.content: Compare technical concepts to everyday experiences.

262.title: Progressive Complexity
262.content: Start simple, add complexity only when needed.

263.title: Error Messages That Help
263.content: Error messages should guide users to solutions.

264.title: Consistent Naming Patterns
264.content: Use the same word for the same concept throughout.

265.title: Avoid Abbreviations
265.content: Write out full words unless universally understood.

266.title: Business Language Over Technical Language
266.content: Use domain terms that business people understand.

267.title: Show Your Work
267.content: Break complex calculations into steps with intermediate variables.

268.title: Fail Gracefully with Helpful Messages
268.content: When something goes wrong, explain what the user should do.

269.title: Test Names That Tell a Story
269.content: Test names should describe the scenario and expected outcome.

270.title: Constants That Explain Themselves
270.content: Use named constants instead of magic numbers.

271.title: NO Advanced Programming Concepts
271.content: BANNED: Closures, decorators, lambda functions, generators, async/await, promises, callbacks

272.title: NO Complex Data Structures
272.content: BANNED: Nested dictionaries, complex objects, arrays of objects

273.title: NO Advanced String Manipulation
273.content: BANNED: Regular expressions, complex string methods

274.title: NO Advanced Control Flow
274.content: BANNED: Switch statements, ternary operators, nested conditions

275.title: NO Advanced Functions
275.content: BANNED: Function overloading, default parameters, rest parameters

276.title: NO Advanced Array Operations
276.content: BANNED: Array methods (map, filter, reduce, forEach, some, every)

278.title: NO Advanced Language Features
278.content: BANNED: TypeScript generics, Python decorators, Java annotations

279.title: NO Advanced Libraries
279.content: BANNED: Third-party libraries, frameworks, complex dependencies

280.title: ENFORCE Simple Level
280.content: MANDATORY: Every line of code must be understandable by an 8th grader

298.title: Snapshot Identity & Integrity  Every snapshot MUST satisfy:
298.content:
Snapshot Identity & Integrity**  Every snapshot MUST satisfy:
- `snapshot_id` pattern: `SNAP.M\d{2}.[a-z0-9_.]+.(v|V)\d+`
- `module_id` pattern: `M\d{2}`
- `snapshot_hash` equal to **sha256** of file contents (hex) prefixed with `sha256:`
- `signature` and `kid` present
- `effective_from` ISO-8601  
Use `tools/gsmd-check.ps1` to verify. Fail CI if any check fails.

314.title: Stop Conditions  GSMD Error Codes  - Writing outside SOT tree .......................... `ERROR:GSMD_SOT_VIOLATION`
314.content:
Stop Conditions  GSMD Error Codes**  - Writing outside SOT tree .......................... `ERROR:GSMD_SOT_VIOLATION`  
- Attempt to modify existing snapshot ............... `ERROR:GSMD_MUTATION_DENIED`  
- Hash mismatch vs `snapshot_hash` .................. `ERROR:GSMD_HASH_MISMATCH`  
- Missing/invalid signature or `kid` ................ `ERROR:GSMD_SIGNATURE_MISSING`  
- Invalid evaluation_point .......................... `ERROR:GSMD_EVALPOINT_INVALID`  
- Receipt missing required fields ................... `ERROR:GSMD_RECEIPT_FIELDS_MISSING`  
- Override missing ttl/approvals/signature .......... `ERROR:GSMD_OVERRIDE_INVALID`  
- Approvals < 2 on override ......................... `ERROR:GSMD_APPROVALS_INSUFFICIENT`  
- Manifest verify (hash/Merkle) fail ................ `ERROR:GSMD_MANIFEST_INVALID`  
- Decision not in allowed set ....................... `ERROR:GSMD_DECISION_INVALID`  
- Privacy redaction not applied ..................... `ERROR:GSMD_PRIVACY_DRIFT`  
- Tests/fixtures absent for declared policy ......... `ERROR:GSMD_TESTS_MISSING`  
- Return contract not honored ....................... `ERROR:GSMD_RETURN_CONTRACT_VIOLATION`

- [ ] Evaluation point valid; decision  {pass,warn,soft_block,hard_block}  
- [ ] Receipt fields complete and signed; values sourced from snapshot  
- [ ] Overrides time-boxed (ttl) with 2 approvals; signed  
- [ ] CI gates added (`gsmd-check`, manifest build/verify)  
- [ ] Privacy redactions applied; no PII/secrets in logs or receipts  
- [ ] Output matches allowed return contract

# Simple Code Readability Rules (Human-Understandable)

 **Purpose:** Make code so simple that anyone can understand it, even an 8th grader. Follow Martin Fowler's principle: "Good programmers write code that humans can understand."

## Scope
Applies to all code, comments, and documentation. Keep changes small and consistent across the codebase.

---

## Basic Readability Rules

316.title: Plain English Variable NamesUse descriptive, everyday words instead of technical jargon or abbreviations.
316.content:
Plain English Variable Names**Use descriptive, everyday words instead of technical jargon or abbreviations.
-  `usr_ctx_mgr`   `user_account_manager`
-  `db_conn_pool`   `database_connections`
-  `cfg_mgr`   `settings_manager`
-  `calc_total`   `calculate_total_price`

317.title: Self-Documenting CodeCode should read like a story, not a puzzle.
317.content:
Self-Documenting Code**Code should read like a story, not a puzzle.
-  `if (x > 0 && y < 100)`   `if (user_age_is_valid && score_is_within_range)`
-  `return calc(x, y, z)`   `return calculate_total_price(quantity, unit_price, tax_rate)`
-  `processUserData()`   `validate_user_email_and_save_to_database()`

318.title: One Concept Per FunctionEach function should do exactly one thing.
318.content:
One Concept Per Function**Each function should do exactly one thing.
- Maximum 20 lines per function
- Function name should clearly describe what it does
- Break complex functions into smaller, focused ones

319.title: Explain the "Why", Not Just the "What"Comments should explain business logic, not code mechanics.
319.content:
Explain the "Why", Not Just the "What"**Comments should explain business logic, not code mechanics.
-  `// Increment counter`   `// Count failed login attempts to detect brute force attacks`
-  `// Loop through array`   `// Check each customer's payment status to identify overdue accounts`

320.title: Avoid Mental GymnasticsNo nested ternary operators, complex one-liners, or clever tricks.
320.content:
Avoid Mental Gymnastics**No nested ternary operators, complex one-liners, or clever tricks.
-  `result = a ? b : c ? d : e`   Use clear if-else statements
-  `return x && y && z ? process() : null`   Break into simple steps

321.title: Use Real-World AnalogiesCompare technical concepts to everyday experiences.
321.content:
Use Real-World Analogies**Compare technical concepts to everyday experiences.
-  `"Database connection pooling"`   `"Like a taxi stand - cars wait for passengers instead of creating new ones each time"`
-  `"API rate limiting"`   `"Like a bouncer at a club - only letting in a certain number of people per minute"`

322.title: Progressive ComplexityStart simple, add complexity only when needed.
322.content:
Progressive Complexity**Start simple, add complexity only when needed.
- Use helper functions to break down complex operations
-  One 100-line function   Five 20-line functions with clear names

323.title: Visual Code LayoutUse whitespace to group related ideas.
323.content:
Visual Code Layout**Use whitespace to group related ideas.
- Align similar operations
- Use consistent indentation (4 spaces)
- Leave blank lines between logical sections

324.title: Error Messages That HelpError messages should guide users to solutions.
324.content:
Error Messages That Help**Error messages should guide users to solutions.
-  `"Error 500"`   `"The email address 'john@' is missing the domain part. Please enter a complete email like 'john@example.com'"`
-  `"Null pointer exception"`   `"The user's profile picture is missing. Please upload a photo or use the default avatar."`

325.title: Consistent Naming PatternsUse the same word for the same concept throughout.
325.content:
Consistent Naming Patterns**Use the same word for the same concept throughout.
-  Mixing `user`, `usr`, `customer`, `client`   Always use `user`
-  Mixing `get`, `fetch`, `retrieve`   Always use `get`

326.title: Avoid AbbreviationsWrite out full words unless universally understood.
326.content:
Avoid Abbreviations**Write out full words unless universally understood.
-  `calc`, `mgr`, `ctx`   `calculate`, `manager`, `context`
-  Allow common ones: `id`, `url`, `api`, `db`

327.title: Business Language Over Technical LanguageUse domain terms that business people understand.
327.content:
Business Language Over Technical Language**Use domain terms that business people understand.
-  `"Execute database transaction"`   `"Save the customer's order"`
-  `"Initialize object instance"`   `"Create a new user account"`

328.title: Show Your WorkBreak complex calculations into steps with intermediate variables.
328.content:
Show Your Work**Break complex calculations into steps with intermediate variables.
-  `return (a * b) + (c * d) - (e / f)`   
[code block]

329.title: Fail Gracefully with Helpful MessagesWhen something goes wrong, explain what the user should do.
329.content:
Fail Gracefully with Helpful Messages**When something goes wrong, explain what the user should do.
- Provide next steps, not just error codes
-  `"Validation failed"`   `"The password must be at least 8 characters long. Please add 3 more characters."`

330.title: Code as DocumentationThe code itself should be the primary documentation.
330.content:
Code as Documentation**The code itself should be the primary documentation.
- Comments should only explain "why", not "what"
- If you need comments to explain "what", the code needs to be clearer

 **Purpose:** Enforce data governance, privacy, and security across the 4-plane ZeroUI storage architecture (IDE, Tenant, Product, Shared).

331.title: Test Names That Tell a StoryTest names should describe the scenario and expected outcome.
331.content:
Test Names That Tell a Story**Test names should describe the scenario and expected outcome.
-  `test_user()`   `test_user_can_login_with_valid_credentials()`
-  `test_error()`   `test_system_shows_helpful_message_when_email_is_invalid()`

332.title: Constants That Explain ThemselvesUse named constants instead of magic numbers.
332.content:
Constants That Explain Themselves**Use named constants instead of magic numbers.
-  `if (age > 18)`   `if (age >= MINIMUM_ADULT_AGE)`
-  `timeout = 5000`   `timeout = FIVE_SECONDS_IN_MILLISECONDS`

## Advanced Concepts (BANNED)

333.title: NO Advanced Programming Concepts-  BANNED: Closures, decorators, lambda functions, generators, async/await, promises, callbacks
333.content:
NO Advanced Programming Concepts**-  **BANNED**: Closures, decorators, lambda functions, generators, async/await, promises, callbacks
-  **BANNED**: Functional programming (map, filter, reduce, fold)
-  **BANNED**: Object-oriented inheritance, polymorphism, abstract classes
-  **BANNED**: Design patterns (singleton, factory, observer, etc.)
-  **ALLOWED**: Simple if-else, for loops, basic functions, simple classes

334.title: NO Complex Data Structures-  BANNED: Nested dictionaries, complex objects, arrays of objects
334.content:
NO Complex Data Structures**-  **BANNED**: Nested dictionaries, complex objects, arrays of objects
-  **BANNED**: Hash maps, sets, tuples, linked lists, trees
-  **BANNED**: JSON parsing, XML parsing, complex serialization
-  **ALLOWED**: Simple arrays, simple objects with 2-3 properties max

335.title: NO Advanced String Manipulation-  BANNED: Regular expressions, complex string methods
335.content:
NO Advanced String Manipulation**-  **BANNED**: Regular expressions, complex string methods
-  **BANNED**: Template literals, string interpolation
-  **BANNED**: Encoding/decoding, base64, hashing
-  **ALLOWED**: Basic string concatenation, simple replace, length check

336.title: NO Complex Error Handling-  BANNED: Try-catch blocks, exception handling, error chains
336.content:
NO Complex Error Handling**-  **BANNED**: Try-catch blocks, exception handling, error chains
-  **BANNED**: Custom error types, error propagation
-  **BANNED**: Retry logic, circuit breakers, fallback mechanisms
-  **ALLOWED**: Simple if-else checks, basic validation
## System Integration & Recovery

337.title: NO Advanced Control Flow-  BANNED: Switch statements, ternary operators, nested conditions
337.content:
NO Advanced Control Flow**-  **BANNED**: Switch statements, ternary operators, nested conditions
-  **BANNED**: Recursion, complex loops, break/continue
-  **BANNED**: Goto statements, early returns in complex functions
-  **ALLOWED**: Simple if-else chains, basic for/while loops

338.title: NO Advanced Functions-  BANNED: Function overloading, default parameters, rest parameters
338.content:
NO Advanced Functions**-  **BANNED**: Function overloading, default parameters, rest parameters
-  **BANNED**: Higher-order functions, function composition
-  **BANNED**: Currying, partial application, function factories
-  **ALLOWED**: Simple functions with 1-3 parameters, basic return statements

339.title: NO Advanced Array Operations-  BANNED: Array methods (map, filter, reduce, forEach, some, every)
339.content:
NO Advanced Array Operations**-  **BANNED**: Array methods (map, filter, reduce, forEach, some, every)
-  **BANNED**: Array destructuring, spread operators
-  **BANNED**: Multi-dimensional arrays, array manipulation
-  **ALLOWED**: Basic array access with [index], simple for loops

340.title: NO Advanced Logic-  BANNED: Boolean algebra, bitwise operations
340.content:
NO Advanced Logic**-  **BANNED**: Boolean algebra, bitwise operations
-  **BANNED**: Complex conditional logic, nested conditions
-  **BANNED**: Logical operators beyond basic AND/OR
-  **ALLOWED**: Simple true/false checks, basic comparisons

341.title: NO Advanced Language Features-  BANNED: TypeScript generics, Python decorators, Java annotations
341.content:
NO Advanced Language Features**-  **BANNED**: TypeScript generics, Python decorators, Java annotations
-  **BANNED**: Advanced JavaScript features, complex type systems
-  **BANNED**: Metaprogramming, reflection, dynamic code generation
-  **ALLOWED**: Basic language syntax only

342.title: NO Advanced Libraries-  BANNED: Third-party libraries, frameworks, complex dependencies
342.content:
NO Advanced Libraries**-  **BANNED**: Third-party libraries, frameworks, complex dependencies
-  **BANNED**: Package managers, dependency management
-  **BANNED**: External APIs, web services, complex integrations
-  **ALLOWED**: Basic language built-ins only

343.title: ENFORCE Simple Level- MANDATORY: Every line of code must be understandable by an 8th grader
343.content:
ENFORCE Simple Level**- **MANDATORY**: Every line of code must be understandable by an 8th grader
- **MANDATORY**: No technical jargon without explanation
- **MANDATORY**: Use simple, everyday words
- **MANDATORY**: Break complex operations into simple steps
- **MANDATORY**: Write code that reads like plain English
- **MANDATORY**: If an 8th grader can't understand it, rewrite it

## Stop Conditions  Error Codes (must refuse & escalate)

**ERROR:ADVANCED_CONCEPT_USED**  Advanced programming concept detected (closures, decorators, etc.)

**ERROR:COMPLEX_DATA_STRUCTURE**  Complex data structure used (nested objects, hash maps, etc.)

**ERROR:JARGON_DETECTED**  Technical jargon without explanation found

**ERROR:MENTAL_GYMNASTICS**  Complex one-liner or nested ternary detected

**ERROR:ABBREVIATION_USED**  Abbreviation used instead of full word

**ERROR:FUNCTION_TOO_LONG**  Function exceeds 20 lines

**ERROR:NESTED_COMPLEXITY**  Nested conditions or complex control flow

**ERROR:READABILITY_FAIL**  Code not understandable at 8th-grade level

**ERROR:TECHNICAL_LANGUAGE**  Technical language used instead of business language

**ERROR:MISSING_EXPLANATION**  Complex concept lacks explanation

**ERROR:COMPLEX_STRING_OPS**  Advanced string manipulation detected

**ERROR:COMPLEX_ERROR_HANDLING**  Try-catch or complex error handling

**ERROR:COMPLEX_CONTROL_FLOW**  Switch, ternary, or recursion detected

**ERROR:COMPLEX_FUNCTIONS**  Function overloading or higher-order functions

**ERROR:COMPLEX_ARRAYS**  Array methods or complex array operations

**ERROR:COMPLEX_LOGIC**  Boolean algebra or bitwise operations

**ERROR:ADVANCED_LANGUAGE_FEATURES**  Generics, decorators, or annotations

**ERROR:ADVANCED_LIBRARIES**  Third-party libraries or frameworks

**ERROR:SIMPLE_LEVEL_VIOLATION**  Code fails 8th-grade readability test



# Good: Simple, readable code
def calculate_total_price(quantity, unit_price, tax_rate):
    # Calculate the base cost before tax

358.title: Rule Conflict Resolution Framework
358.content: Establish formal conflict resolution when testing rules contradict other constitutional rules. Security rules always take precedence over testing requirements.

359.title: Cross-Constitution Validation Gateway
359.content: Validate no contradictions exist between Testing Constitution and Master Constitution documents. Ensure testing requirements don't violate core system principles.

360.title: Module Identity Integrity Validation
360.content: Ensure Module IDs (M01-M20) maintain consistent identity mapping across GSMD folders, Extension modules, and policy version IDs used by test systems.

361.title: Version Compatibility Matrix Enforcement
361.content: Standardize and enforce version compatibility between Testing Constitution and Master/Module rule sets through automated matrix validation.

362.title: Test Lifecycle Coverage Mandate
362.content: Require comprehensive test coverage for all system lifecycle states including deprecation, migration, rollback, and configuration inheritance scenarios.

363.title: Automated Compliance Evidence Generation
363.content: Mandate automated generation of compliance evidence bundles for every PR proving constitutional adherence across all rule sets.

364.title: Testing Rule Metadata Standardization
364.content: Enforce standardized metadata requirements for all testing constitution rules to ensure consistency and machine-readability.

365.title: Standardized Test Reporting Framework
365.content: Establish mandatory standardized reporting formats for all test executions including both human-readable and machine-processable outputs.

366.title: Add Module Procedure
366.content: To add a module: create both canonical folders (STR-003/STR-004); add required snapshots and keys (SCH-001SCH-006); then pass all CI checks (VAL-001VAL-007).

367.title: Remove Module Procedure
367.content: To remove a module: delete both canonical folders; update any enumerations/mappings; re-run CI to ensure no dangling references (VAL-001).

368.title: Require Core Snapshot Files
368.content:
Each GSMD module MUST contain:
 `messages/v1/snapshot.json` with `messages.problems`, `messages.status_pill`, `messages.cards`
 `receipts_schema/v1/snapshot.json` with `receipts.required`, `receipts.optional`

369.title: Require Top-Level Fields in All Snapshots
369.content: Every `.../v1/snapshot.json` MUST include all required top-level fields defined in the Constitution.

371.title: Enforce Single Policy Version ID
371.content: `policy_version_ids` MUST be an array of length 1.

374.title: Enforce Module-Folder Binding
374.content: Specifies exact folder paths for each module code (M01M20) in both VS Code extension and GSMD directories.

375.title: Enforce Module Code as Primary Key
375.content: Establishes module code (M01M20) as primary identifier for all folder bindings.

376.title: Require Extension Folder Path
376.content: For each MXX, the extension folder MUST exist at `src/modules/mXX-<slug>/`.

377.title: Require GSMD Folder Path
377.content: For each MXX, the GSMD folder MUST exist at `gsmd/gsmd/modules/MXX/`.

378.title: CI: Verify Canonical Folders per Module
378.content: For each MXX, assert exactly one extension folder at `src/modules/mXX-<slug>/` and exactly one GSMD folder at `gsmd/gsmd/modules/MXX/`.

379.title: CI: Validate Top-Level Snapshot Fields
379.content: Validate that every `.../v1/snapshot.json` contains all required top-level fields.

385.title: Prioritize Determinism Over Speed
385.content: Reproducible test runs are superior to fast but flaky runs.

386.title: Eliminate Test-Result Caching
386.content: Disable or purge all framework caches before every run.

387.title: Enforce Hermetic Test Runs
387.content: Tests must not access network, system clocks, global OS state, or previous runs.

388.title: Maintain Test Independence
388.content: Tests must pass when run alone or in any sequence.

389.title: Maintain Standard Repository Structure
389.content: Use src/, tests/ with subdirectories unit/, component/, integration/, fixtures/, helpers/.

391.title: Purge Cache Directories Pre-Execution
391.content: Delete Python, Node.js, and tooling caches before test execution.

392.title: Disable Framework Caching
392.content: Use framework-specific flags to disable caching mechanisms.

393.title: Maintain Unit Test Purity
393.content: Unit tests must be pure functions with no I/O, network, or time dependencies.

394.title: Use Table-Driven Test Structure
394.content: Unit tests must use table-driven tests for clarity.

395.title: Use In-Memory Doubles for Component Tests
395.content: Component tests must use in-memory doubles only for cross-module interactions.

396.title: Use Real Adapters for Integration Tests
396.content: Integration tests must use real adapters with isolated instances.

397.title: Prohibit Internet Access in Tests
397.content: No calls to public Internet in unit, component, or integration tests.

398.title: Control Randomness and Time
398.content: All randomness must be seeded; time must be frozen or explicitly controlled.

399.title: Prohibit Test Retries
399.content: Flaky tests are bugs; do not mask with retries.

400.title: Organize Fixtures and Data
400.content: Fixtures under tests/fixtures/, read-only, prefer synthetic data, hash large fixtures.

401.title: Generate Test Evidence
401.content: Emit jUnit XML reports and run manifest with seeds, versions, and hashes.

402.title: Design AI-Generated Tests Deterministically
402.content: Assume cache purging, use TEST_RANDOM_SEED, compose hermetic tests.

403.title: Organize AI-Generated Tests Properly
403.content: Place tests in correct directories, use pure helpers, minimize dependencies.

404.title: Ensure AI-Generated Test Quality
404.content: Limit test scope, provide complete implementations, create actionable failures.

405.title: Enforce Quality Gates
405.content: All tests must pass, no network access, valid artifacts, cache elimination verified.

406.title: Conduct Comprehensive Test Reviews
406.content: Verify determinism, completeness, organization, harness usage, artifacts, cache elimination.

407.title: Enforce Static Package Contributions
407.content: All package.json contributions (commands, menus, views, keybindings, configuration) must be statically defined at package build time. Runtime modification or dynamic addition of VS Code extension contributions is strictly prohibited.

408.title: Restrict Scope to IDE Surfaces Only
408.content: The extension scope is strictly limited to IDE-only surfaces including Status Pill, Decision Card, Evidence Drawer, Quick Actions, and Receipt. Web UI development is explicitly excluded from scope.

409.title: Exclude Server and Policy Definitions
409.content: This constitution governs only the VS Code extension architecture and explicitly excludes definitions for server endpoints or policy content.

410.title: Ensure Fast Extension Activation
410.content: The extension activation function must return quickly, with all heavy initialization work deferred to command handlers to prevent VS Code startup delays.

411.title: Implement Context Key Driven Menus
411.content: All menu visibility and enablement must be controlled through VS Code context keys using setContext commands and when clauses.

412.title: Standardize Single Status Bar Item
412.content: The extension must use a single shared Status Bar item with composition logic rather than multiple individual status items.

413.title: Enforce Single Extension Artifact
413.content: The repository must produce and distribute exactly one VS Code extension artifact. Multi-extension packaging is strictly prohibited.

414.title: Maintain Canonical Directory Structure
414.content: The project must exactly follow the authoritative directory structure defined in the constitution without deviation.

415.title: Isolate Core Framework Code
415.content: The src/core/ directory must contain only shared framework code. Product-specific logic is strictly prohibited in core.

416.title: Contain Features in Module Directories
416.content: All feature implementation code must reside within src/modules/<slug>/ directories with the specified file structure.
